Antonie van Leeuwenhoek was the first person to see unicellular microbes.
Robert Hooke called the pores in cork 'cells'.
Schleiden and Schwann formulated the cell doctrine.
The cell doctrine states that all living organisms are made of cells and that cells are alive.
Cells are the unit of life.
Cells can be divided into prokaryotes and eukaryotes.
Prokaryotes are cells without a nucleus and include bacteria.
Eukaryotes are cells with a nucleus.
Multicellular animals and plants are eukaryotes.
Cells metabolize, replicate, grow, and divide.
Cells are surrounded by a membrane and are filled with cytoplasm.
Eukaryotic cells subdivide their cytoplasm with internal membranes to generate organelles.
Organelles like the nucleus contain genes.
The most common chemical elements that make up the inanimate world are oxygen, silicon, aluminum, and iron.
Living organisms are composed of oxygen, hydrogen, carbon, and nitrogen.
Oxygen, silicon, aluminum, and iron comprise about 90% of the Earth's crust.
Oxygen, hydrogen, carbon, and nitrogen make up 99% of our bodies.
The chemistry of life is, for the most part, the chemistry of carbon.
Much of what goes on in our bodies is based on the ability of carbon to react and interact with oxygen, hydrogen, and nitrogen.
Organic chemistry is the chemistry of carbon.
70% of our bodies are made of water.
30% of our body are made mainly of macromolecules.
Macromolecules are generally polymers.
Macromolecules are molecular complexes made up of many small building blocks or subunits called monomers linked together to form long extended chains.
Sugar monomers can combine to form polymers of sugar, called polysaccharides.
Polysaccharides are important for storing energy.
Proteins are polymers made up of monomers called amino acids.
There are 20 different amino acids.
Proteins are the workhorse of the cell.
All enzymes are proteins.
Enzymes digest our food and build our bodies.

אתנול קוטבי בגלל קבוצת ההידרוקסיל אך הוא קוטבי פחות מאשר המים, בגלל אטומי הפחמן והמימן הנוספים.
אתנול רותח בטמפרטורה נמוכה יותר, 78 מעלות צלזיוס, ומתאדה בקלות רבה יותר ממים, מפני שקשרי מימן מעטים יותר וחלשים מחזיקים את המולקולות ביחד.
מולקולות שמכילות פחמן, מולקולות אורגניות, יכולות להיות קוטביות יותר או פחות, כתלות במספר הקבוצות הקוטביות שהן מכילות.
ככל שהמולקולה קוטבית יותר, גדלה הסבירות שהיא תגיב עם מולקולות המים שבסביבתה באמצעות קשרי מימן, ולכן תהיה "הידרופילית".
אם מולקולה אינה מכילה קבוצות קוטביות, היא אינה מסוגלת לקיים קשר מימן עם המים. במקרה זה, היא נקראת "הידורופובית", מפחדת ממים.
תמיסה הידרופילית אינה מתערבבת עם נוזלים הידרופוביים, ולכן, מים אינם מתערבבים עם שמן.
כאשר מוסיפים קבוצות הידרוקסיל למולקולות אורגניות הן נהיות הידרופיליות יותר ויותר.
אם מאריכים את שרשראות אטומי הפחמן והמימן, שרשראות פחמימנים, המולקולה הופכת להיות הידרופובית יותר.
כמה מולקולות הן מעט "סכיזופרניות" בכך שהן מכילות חלקים הידרופיליים והידרופוביים בו זמנית. החומרים הללו הם "אמפיפתיים", כלומר, הם בעלי שני המאפיינים. הם גם הידרופוביים וגם הידרופיליים.

The most common chemical elements that make up the inanimate world are oxygen, silicon, aluminum, and iron.
These four elements comprise just about 90% of the Earth's crust.
Oxygen, along with hydrogen, carbon, and nitrogen, make up 99% of our bodies.
The chemistry of life is, for the most part, the chemistry of carbon.
Much of what goes on in our bodies is based on the unique ability of carbon to react and interact with oxygen, hydrogen, and nitrogen.
The chemistry of carbon is in a class of its own and is referred to as organic chemistry.
70% of our bodies are made of water.
30% of our body are made mainly of very large molecules called macromolecules.
Generally, macromolecules are polymers.
Molecular complexes made up of many small building blocks or subunits are called monomers.
Sugar monomers like glucose can combine to form polymers of sugar, called polysaccharides.
Polysaccharides are important for storing energy.
Proteins are polymers, too.
Proteins are made up of monomers called amino acids.
There are 20 different amino acids.
Proteins are the workhorse of the cell.
All enzymes, for example, are proteins.

The protective coat of keratin armor is constantly replenished as the lowermost keratinocytes of the epidermis continually divide and provide new layers of cells that are pushed up to the surface.

The immune system deals with recognizing pathogens as foreign and systematically knocks them out.
Much of our immune system flows in our blood and reaches all corners of our body.

Some cells of our immune system act as sentries, the macrophages reside in our tissues, and when they encounter a pathogen that has breached our skin, they engage in battle and sound the alarm to recruit neutrophils.
Our white blood cells are in essence the cells of our immune system.
White blood cells are generally of two types: phagocytes and lymphocytes.
Phagocytes, such as macrophages and neutrophils, are central to our innate immune response.
The innate immune response is immediate and fast acting, but has no memory.
Macrophages recognize pathogens via PRRs that bind PAMPs.
Lymphocytes are the main soldiers of the adaptive immune response.
Adaptive immunity is slower to kick in, but more powerful, exquisitely specific, and generates memory.
The memory of the adaptive immune response is what protects us, when we encounter pathogens a second time.
In addition to our white blood cells, the microbiome is an important factor ensuring good health.
The presence of native microflora competes against pathogens.
Innate immunity can raise mechanical barriers to infection, external and internal barriers.
The external barrier is our skin, made up of epidermis and dermis.
The cells of epidermis are referred to as keratinocytes.
The internal barrier is our mucosa, which secretes mucus.
Mucus is a sticky fluid, which can entrap viruses and bacteria.
One chemical barrier is, in essence, the acidity of our stomach, our gastric juices.
